titleStmt.title: The Temporal Dynamics of Attitudinal Conflict in Daily Life: An Experience Sampling Study of Conflict Emergence and Resolution in the Context of Meat Consumption

affiliation.orgName: National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM)

analytic.title: The Temporal Dynamics of Attitudinal Conflict in Daily Life: An Experience Sampling Study of Conflict Emergence and Resolution in the Context of Meat Consumption

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Although attitudinal conflict is a pervasive aspect of everyday decision-making, little is known about the temporal dynamics that characterize how people experience and resolve such conflict. The present research investigated attitudinal conflict by adopting a temporal framework of conflict emergence and resolution. We conducted a preregistered experience sampling study in the domain of meat consumption and employed a novel integrated sampling approach (of a total of 18,586 observations from 462 participants), achieving precise temporal resolution throughout the entire course of natural decision-making processes in daily life. The data revealed an episodic structure of attitudinal conflict, highlighting a complex trajectory across multiple phases. Especially when people engaged in decision-making, the cognitive accessibility of evaluative inconsistency (i.e., attitudinal ambivalence) elicited conflict. Although these experiences emerged situationally, they tended to fade gradually. People downregulated attitudinal conflict more strongly when they ate meat despite previously evaluating it negatively (i.e., cognitive dissonance). However, this decline was only temporary, and the conflict resurged. Furthermore, people engaged in dissonance reduction by initially denying responsibility for eating meat and subsequently aligning their attitudes. The findings elucidate the situational dynamics and sequential processes underlying how people struggle with conflicted choices and rationalize them in everyday life. Furthermore, given that our sampling method offers finegrained insights into the entire decision-making process, it can be applied to various research questions and applications, such as to inform the optimal timing of behavior change campaigns.

div.head: The temporal dynamics of Attitudinal conflict in daily life: An experience sampling study of attitudinal ambivalence and dissonance reduction in the context of meat consumption
div.p: Forming opinions and making decisions is an integral part of life. However, attitudinal conflicts pervade a wide range of daily activities and life events, including health behavior, interpersonal relations, and morality (Effron & Helgason, 2023;Hillman et al., 2022;. Such conflicts threaten basic needs by impeding effective action and causing distress (Cialdini et al., 1995;Vaccaro et al., 2020;van Harreveld et al., 2015;Zoppolat et al., 2023).

Prolonged periods of attitudinal conflicts, therefore, present an opportunity for supporting individuals in resolving the unpleasant experience of conflict and in their pursuit of behavior change (Emmons & King, 1988;Prochaska, 2008;Prochaska & DiClemente, 1983).

Given the intricate nature of intra-individual conflict, the phenomenon lies at the heart of a variety of influential psychological theories (E. Jonas et al., 2014;Proulx et al., 2012), many themes of which can be traced back to cognitive dissonance theory (Cooper & Fazio, 1984;Festinger, 1957).

Those theories have conceptualized how attitudinal conflict arises and dissolves within individuals (e.g., Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Janis & Mann, 1977;Moore & Martin, 2022;van Harreveld et al., 2015). Despite the inherently multi-sequential course of experiencing and regulating attitudinal conflict over time, research on these temporal structures is limited. Moreover, most research on the topic has been conducted in laboratories without observing its naturally occurring dynamics (A. McGrath, 2017;Vaidis & Bran, 2019). This aligns with the widespread lack of ecologically valid research on the temporal aspects inherent to psychological experiences, which hampers theory development and scientific progress (Diener et al., 2022;Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023;Hopwood et al., 2022;Yarkoni, 2022).

In the present research, we investigated how people experience and react to attitudinal conflict by taking a temporal perspective on the processes involved. Our study therefore employed intensive longitudinal methods in everyday life (i.e., experience sampling methods, ESM; Csikszentmihalyi & Larson, 1987;Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023), along with a novel integrated sampling approach, to illuminate the entire process of how attitudinal conflict arises and dissolves naturally over time. We obtained high-resolution insights into the processes proposed in our framework of conflict emergence and resolution by tracking them throughout everyday instances of decision-making. In this way, we refine and test central yet implicit assertions from prevailing conflict theories in daily life.

div.head: The Experience of Attitudinal Conflict
div.p: One of the earliest and most influential theories on psychological conflict is cognitive dissonance theory (Festinger, 1957) that conceptualized how conflicting cognitions motivate people to reduce the ensuing discomfort from the perceived inconsistency. Festinger argued that various types of knowledge and experiences can elicit dissonance, including opinions, beliefs, and perceptions of behavior. Ample research has investigated dissonance in how people react to experiences that contradict their attitudes (Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020;Harmon-Jones, 2019). For instance, dissonance arises from performing a discomforting action to attain a goal (i.e., effort justification; Aronson & Mills, 1959) and when choosing between two equally favorable options (Brehm, 1956).

Such situations elicit attitudinal conflict especially if they entail feelings of responsibility for aversive consequences (Cooper & Fazio, 1984;but see Sleegers et al., 2023), jeopardize a favorable self-image (Steele, 1988), or impede effective action (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Harmon-Jones et al., 2009).

While the dissonance literature focuses on how people resolve attitudinal conflicts that usually involve a behavioral commitment (Gawronski & Brannon, 2019;K. Jonas et al., 2000;McGregor et al., 2019), research on attitudinal ambivalence investigates intra-attitudinal conflict people experience before committing to a behavior or outside of a behavioral context altogether (Cacioppo et al., 1997;Conner & Armitage, 2008;.

Ambivalence research distinguishes between structurally inconsistent attitudes (potential ambivalence) and metacognitive awareness of the inconsistency, which entails experiencing attitudinal conflict (felt ambivalence; Schneider & Schwarz, 2017). This distinction has further elucidated when people experience conflict, which depends on the evaluative components underlying the ambivalent attitude and their relevance to a person's goals (e.g., DeMarree et al., 2014;Petty et al., 2006;Toribio-Flórez et al., 2020). Ambivalent attitudes lead to conflict especially if they involve a similar magnitude of highly positive and negative evaluations, with increases in the comparably less pronounced evaluative components engendering attitudinal conflict (Dalege et al., 2019;Priester & Petty, 1996;Snyder & Tormala, 2017).

People experience attitudinal conflict especially if the inconsistent evaluative components are of equal strength and simultaneously accessible (Newby-Clark et al., 2002;Nohlen et al., 2016). The most common instance that co-activates the inconsistent evaluations is arguably when an individual has to make a decision about an ambivalent attitude object (Schneider et al., 2015;. Such choice situations should render pre-existing inconsistencies salient as people have to commit to one side of the ambivalent attitude and elaborate on it to reach a decision (van Harreveld et al., 2015). In this vein, the impact of evaluative inconsistency on attitudinal conflict depends on situational factors that evoke a desire for consistency.

While attitudinal conflict may therefore usually be an episodic state, the underlying ambivalent attitude constitutes a more stable but dormant propensity to experience conflict (Emmons & King, 1988;Keller & Siegrist, 2015). As such, attitudinal conflict might sometimes dissolve on its own due to distraction and forgetting (Zanna & Aziza, 1976). As attitudinal conflict entails aversive discomfort like feelings of uncertainty and anticipated regret (Itzchakov & van Harreveld, 2018;Nohlen et al., 2014;van Harreveld, Rutjens, et al., 2009), however, multifaceted coping strategies facilitate its regulation (Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020;Rothman et al., 2017;van Harreveld et al., 2015).

These coping strategies are conceptualized to alleviate the discomfort experienced during attitudinal conflict (i.e., emotion-focused coping) or generate greater consistency (i.e., problemfocused coping; Buttlar, Pauer, & van Harreveld, 2024;van Harreveld et al., 2015), such as by seeking out information that helps resolve the inconsistency (Nordgren et al., 2006;Pauer, Rutjens, Ruby, et al., 2022). In coping with attitudinal conflict, people need to balance accurate and efficient conflict regulation with the effort involved . When engaging in counter-attitudinal behavior that is irreversible, it becomes therefore easier to mitigate the discomfort of attitudinal conflict rather than its underlying source (Bullens et al., 2013;Festinger, 1957;Harmon-Jones et al., 2009). Such dissonance reduction leads people to align their attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors with past behavior to reduce the experience of attitudinal conflict (Aronson et al., 1991;Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020;Cooper, 2007). This involves, for example, changing the contradictory attitude (Brehm, 1956), denying the consequences of the behavior (e.g., Bastian et al., 2012;Loughnan et al., 2010), or denying responsibility for it (Gosling et al., 2006;Rothgerber et al., 2022). The latter may absolve individuals from the perception of choice and thus diminish the accessibility of the evaluative inconsistency that led to the attitudinal conflict (Gosling et al., 2006;. Despite extensive research illuminating the antecedents and consequences of attitudinal conflict (Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020;Harmon-Jones, 2019;Rothman et al., 2017), the temporal nature of how people experience attitudinal conflict and cope with it remains underspecified. The following section elaborates on the need for ecologically valid insights into the temporal dynamics of these processes in the emergence and regulation of attitudinal conflict.

div.head: The Temporal Dynamics of Attitudinal Conflict
div.p: Psychological theorizing often hinges on assumptions about the temporal nature of human experiences, yet these temporal dynamics remain largely implicit, underspecified, and untested (Diener et al., 2022;Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023;Hopwood et al., 2022;Schwarz, 2012). In the context of experiences of attitudinal conflict, the temporal dimension becomes apparent in prevailing models that propose sequential processes in how they arise and dissolve in the real world (e.g., Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020;Harmon-Jones, 2019;. However, only few studies have investigated these temporal patterns of conflict, their within-subject processes, or instances of naturally evolving conflict (e.g., Hormes & Rozin, 2011;Jarcho et al., 2011;Schneider et al., 2015). Empirical insight into how attitudinal conflict and its consequences unfold over time comes from studies measuring physiological arousal during the writing of an essay on a conflicted topic (Martinie et al., 2013;van Harreveld, Rutjens, et al., 2009). In this setting, attitudinal conflict surged during making an initial choice on a topic and subsequently lingered. Furthermore, long-term longitudinal studies on attitudinal conflict have indicated the durability of its consequences over several months (Finkhäuser et al., 2024;Janis & Mann, 1965;Sénémeaud & Somat, 2009).

While the aforementioned studies provide tentative insight into the temporal characteristics of how attitudinal conflict arises and dissolves, the literature remains inconclusive for three reasons: (a) exclusive reliance on laboratory experiments or retrospective and prospective self-reports (Diener et al., 2022;Schwarz, 2012;Yarkoni, 2022), (b) oversimplified comparisons between groups and prepost measurements (Brandt & Morgan, 2022;Diener et al., 2022;Hamaker, 2012), and (c) imprecise time resolutions (Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023;Hopwood et al., 2022;J. E. McGrath & Tschan, 2004). These pitfalls can lead to producing erroneous conclusions, especially in studying processes that evolve within an individual (Brandt & Morgan, 2022;Hamaker, 2012;Hopwood et al., 2022).

For instance, laboratory settings could produce different dynamics related to attitudinal conflict than naturalistic settings, given that the latter arguably entails flexibility in switching between various regulation strategies over time (A. McGrath, 2017;Vaidis & Bran, 2019;Walster et al., 1967).

Therefore, real-time observations of the time course of dynamics as they unfold naturally are imperative for testing and refining psychological theories (Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023;Yarkoni, 2022). To address this gap in the literature, we examined the trajectory and temporal dynamics of attitudinal conflict in daily life so as to better understand the processes through which attitudinal conflict emerges and is eventually resolved.

div.head: Overview of the Present Work
div.p: We conducted a preregistered intensive longitudinal study using experience sampling methods (ESM; Csikszentmihalyi & Larson, 1987) to investigate the antecedents and consequences of attitudinal conflict throughout daily life. Leveraging the high ecological validity and a fine-grained resolution of within-person processes offered by ESM (Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023;Mehl et al., 2012;Trull & Ebner-Priemer, 2013), our research investigates a comprehensive framework of conflict emergence and resolution. We adopt a temporal perspective in examining the situational dynamics and natural processes underlying why attitudinal conflict arises and how people respond to it (see Figure 1).

The first part of our framework draws on the assertion that attitudinal conflict arises especially in decisional situations that make inconsistent evaluations simultaneously accessible. Based on the model of ambivalence-induced discomfort (MAID;, we expected that people experience attitudinal conflict when a conflicted choice is imminent. If they feel responsible for making a decision and elaborate on its outcomes, these situations arguably give rise to conflict by heightening the cognitive accessibility of inconsistent evaluations. Conditional on the accessibility of inconsistent positive and negative evaluations and their magnitude, the effect of inconsistency on conflict should peak during decision-making. The salience of evaluative inconsistency might also vary due to situational factors like stress and hunger (Critchley & Harrison, 2013;Schwarz, 2007), potentially diminishing the impact of the urge to make a decision on the experience of attitudinal conflict.

We propose that attitudinal conflict peaks in a nonlinear fashion, characterized by an inversely U-shaped turning point in its trajectory upon making a choice. This prediction is informed by cross-sectional studies that suggest a slanted and inverse U-shaped peak in the emergence and resolution of dispositional attitudinal conflict among individuals who contemplate behavior change compared to those who have already changed their behavior or choose not to do so (Armitage & Arden, 2007;Buttlar, Pauer, Ruby, et al., 2024). Furthermore, one can expect experiences of attitudinal conflict to exhibit low transcience, such that they remain salient for an extended period of time (Finkhäuser et al., 2024;van Harreveld, Rutjens, et al., 2009). Once people start engaging in counter-attitudinal behavior, however, we assume that they will promptly initiate the downregulation of attitudinal conflict to facilitate effective action-taking, in line with the action-based model of dissonance and the motivated account of moral reasoning (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Harmon-Jones et al., 2009). Our ESM study therefore focused on observing the regulatory dynamics in response to naturally occuring dissonance from enacting counter-attitudinal behavior.

The dynamics of how people respond to attitudinal conflict may involve problem-focused coping (e.g., evaluative spreading) and emotion-focused coping (e.g., responsibility diffusion; . We argue that attitudinal conflict motivates a sequential interplay of these regulatory processes. While numerous empirical studies have suggested that people engage in only a single attempt to resolve attitudinal conflict (e.g., Gosling et al., 2006;Rothgerber, 2020;Simon et al., 1995), these studies have not tested the assertion that the process of conflict regulation could involve a cascade of resolution attempts over prolonged time windows (Abelson, 1959;Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020;Cooper, 2007;Vaidis & Bran, 2019). As such, conflict regulation could evolve through relatively brief and presumably even habitual or automatic processes (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020), but also over an extended period of conflict regulation.

The temporary downregulation of attitudinal conflict could last throughout the enactment of a conflicted choice outcome in order to avert attitudinal conflict from impeding the course of action (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Harmon-Jones et al., 2009). Ultimately, when attention to a conflicted choice ceases, the need to regulate the conflict could diminish as a result of reduced accessibility of inconsistency and through the process of forgetting over time (E. Jonas et al., 2001;McGregor et al., 2019;Zanna & Aziza, 1976). However, the attitudinal conflict could reappear subsequently, such as due to prior suppression of the conflict (Pauer, Rutjens, et al., 2023;Wegner et al., 1987). Given that people arguably regulate attitudinal conflict by engaging in effortless coping strategies if these are effective (Festinger, 1957;, an endurance or reappearance of the conflict could be accompanied by more effortful attempts to reconcile the ambivalent attitude and avert the conflict from reappearing (Pauer, Rutjens, et al., 2023).

div.head: Conceptual Model of Conflict Emergence and Resolution as Investigated in the Current Research
div.p: To shed light on the naturally occurring processes in how attitudinal conflict arises and dissolves, we examined our proposed framework utilizing the domain of meat consumption and focused on the dynamics of attitudinal conflict and its consequences around food choices. Extensive research has investigated meat-related attitudinal ambivalence and cognitive dissonance (Bastian, 2019;Bastian et al., 2012;Berndsen & van der Pligt, 2004;Buttlar & Walther, 2018;Conner et al., 2020;De Groeve & Rosenfeld, 2021;Rothgerber et al., 2022;Rothgerber & Rosenfeld, 2021), demonstrating that experiencing such conflicts is widespread (Buttlar et al., 2023;Pauer, Rutjens, Ruby, et al., 2022;Ruby et al., 2016;Ton et al., 2023). This prevalence is due to food choice being an oftentimes intricate yet inevitable part of daily life (Becker et al., 2019;Rozin, 2007). Specifically, most people hold both positive and negative evaluations about meat, attributable to its pleasure and cultural entrenchment, as well as its detrimental consequences on farmed animals, sustainability, and personal health (Buttlar et al., 2023;Eurobarometer, 2016;Hartmann & Siegrist, 2020;Willett et al., 2019). Rozin (2007, p. 404) has therefore argued that meat represents "a quintessential example of […] ambivalence". Importantly, the domain of meat consumption provides a relatively high frequency of trackable decisions about food choices across individuals, marked by a pronounced period of enacting conflicted behavior with an unequivocal reference point for its onset. This allows us to delineate the temporal stages of attitudinal conflict throughout decision-making: Prior to consuming a meal, people experience the conflict as felt ambivalence, whereas cognitive dissonance becomes predominant upon consuming a meal (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Buttlar, Pauer, & van Harreveld, 2024;. The case example of meat consumption therefore allows us to harness a powerful synergy between experience sampling methods (ESM) and a novel integrated sampling approach for assessing high-resolution observations of attitudinal conflict and its dynamic processes across the entire span of decision-making as these processes evolve naturally in the real world (see Note that the preregistration includes a section of hypotheses for a separate research project on the inter-temporal frequency of ambivalence and its consequences. For this reason, the dataset will be made openly accessible before acceptance of the present paper or upon request. The present manuscript follows JARS and transparently reports how we determined the sample size, as well as all data exclusions and measures in the study (Appelbaum et al., 2018). The analyses were ran in R 4.2.2 (R Core Team, 2020) using the packages mgcv (Wood, 2017), lme4 (Bates et al., 2014), and ancillary packages (see R code). Ethics approval was obtained from a large Dutch University.

div.head: Participants
div.p: The final sample comprised 462 U.K. participants recruited from Prolific (51% female, 48% male, 2 non-binary, 3% unemployed, 7% students, Mage = 36.92, SDage = 9.64). Compared to other experience sampling studies, our relatively large sample comprised a heterogeneous set of sociodemographic characteristics (Myin-Germeys & Kuppens, 2021). Participants completed a total of 18,586 experience sampling method surveys (ESM), corresponding to an excellent completion rate of 80.5%. This provided a fine-grained temporal resolution, averaging 36 observations per minute in our main models.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: People who passed a screening survey for a "smartphone-based diary study" were invited to participate in a multi-day study, which included a cover story on well-being. Smartphone owners with Android and iOS operating systems were eligible for the study. Given that we employed the domain of attitudinal conflict about meat consumption, we invited only meat eaters, as strict meat avoiders would represent a small group of people who experience different food-related conflicts than meat eaters Buttlar et al., 2023;Buttlar, Pauer, Ruby, et al., 2024). A total of 489 participants responded to the intake form, which explained the ESM procedures and assessed sociodemographic information and dispositional scales. After installing the ExpiWell smartphone app (Tay, 2023) for the mobile phase, 478 people completed a test-run mobile survey, which was not included in any analyses, as per the preregistration. Subsequently, they continued with the intake form, and the 5-day mobile phase started the next day. Each day between 10 am and 9 pm, participants were asked to complete eight signal-contingent surveys, for which they received notifications at random time points within stratified intervals, as well as meal reports at each lunch and dinner (see Figure 2). Participants received up to £22.50 and automatically entered a raffle for £150.

Given the complexity in modeling the statistical power of multilevel growth models, our preregistered goal was to achieve a final sample size of at least 400 participants, in order to exceed the recommended numbers for ESM studies and time analysis (Gabriel et al., 2019;Hecht & Zitzmann, 2021). We excluded data as per the preregistered quality checks: Nine ESM surveys were excluded due to a median speed per item of less than 1 second, and nine participants were excluded because they failed at least one out of three attention checks (e.g., "Right now, please select six") in the intake form and the mobile phase.

div.head: Analysis Strategy
div.p: Multilevel Growth Models. We utilized a multilevel framework to analyze the intensive longitudinal data, as per the preregistration. The use of multilevel models was warranted by a significant intercept-only model that predicted attitudinal conflict while controlling for betweenperson variance, p < .001, which indicated that within-subjects fluctuations explained 23% of the variance in conflict. Level-1 predictors were nested within participants and person-mean centered (Enders & Tofighi, 2007;Hox, 2018). The centered variables reflect within-person changes over time, such that the models probed the effects of a person's deviation from their average state on the dependent variables.

Multilevel growth models with time as a predictor allowed us to model temporal trajectories of the dependent variables, and we utilized interaction terms between time and other predictors to qualify why the dependent variables fluctuated over time (Grimm et al., 2017;Hoffman, 2015;Hoffman & Walters, 2022). The data for most of the growth models included 13,932 rows, reflecting aggregates of the meal reports and signal-contingent surveys (explained below; the Supplement reports all sample sizes).

The Time Variable. The growth models employed a time variable as an independent variable that represents the temporal proximity of a measurement point to the onset of the nearest meal, as per the preregistration. The variable was calculated from the recorded times of signal-contingent surveys and the starting time of food intake, as reported at each meal. This approach integrated signalcontingent with event-contingent data, locating each observation of psychological states at a precise time point in relation to naturally occurring food choices (see Figure 2).

Larger values of the time variable indicate a greater temporal distance from a meal, with negative values occurring before food intake. The 0-point corresponds to the onset of food intake. For interpretation purposes, the time variable was therefore modeled as an uncentered predictor. Given that skipped meals substantially increased the distance from a measurement to the nearest food intake, we replaced the corresponding values of the time variable with the overall values at 2 SD below or above the mean of the time variable (i.e., winsorization of a total of 1.5% of the time variable's values). This approach prevents interference at the tails of the distribution of the time variable (Wood, 2017), while also precluding data loss and ensuring a high density of observations per minute, with a median of 36 (the median among the winsorized outliers was 2).

Rolling Correlation Analysis. We used rolling correlation analysis (also termed running or moving correlations) to model changes in the associations of variables across time (Cabrieto et al., 2018;Houben et al., 2020;Zivot & Wang, 2003). In analogy to the more familiar moving average, this method employs consecutive correlation analyses within moving time windows (e.g., Dejonckheere et al., 2019;Pauling et al., 2006;Scheffer et al., 2009). Specifically, we calculated a Pearson correlation coefficient for two variables within a window of observations that moved across the time variable for each correlation analysis. As per the preregistration, we estimated rolling correlations between felt and potential ambivalence, as well as between positive and negative evaluations (i.e., evaluative spreading). The time windows were 12 and 15 observations, respectively, selected based on model fit. For the simple slope analysis of dissonance-induced evaluative spreading, the optimal model fit was achieved with a window size of 14. The calculated variables of rolling correlation coefficients were analyzed as dependent variables in growth models. These models estimated the trajectories of change in the rolling correlations over time.
Generalized Additive Models. We preregistered analyses of nonlinear trends across time.

These trajectories were estimated using spline regression with generalized additive modeling (GAM; Hastie & Tibshirani, 1986) in the R package mgcv (Wood, 2017). GAM is a flexible but robust approach for model estimation and time analysis, and it has been frequently used in psychological science (e.g., Buecker et al., 2021;Burger, 2024;Kuppens et al., 2013;Major et al., 2014;Rodman et al., 2023;Smiley & Fisher, 2022). GAM is preferable over alternative methods like polynomial regression and segmented regression as it minimizes overfitted trajectories through penalized model fit and requires no predictions regarding exact breakpoints in the shape of a trajectory (Breit et al., 2023;McKeown & Sneddon, 2014). For cross-validation, the supplement reports a polynomial multilevel regression of our base model with converging evidence (see Table S1 and Figure S1). As GAM precludes traditional simple slope analyses of multilevel interactions between continuous variables, we employed a multi-group paradigm with median splits to estimate simple slopes within GAM (DeCoster et al., 2011;Iacobucci et al., 2015;Wood, 2017). To estimate nonlinear effects, we employed standard smooth terms (i.e., smoothing independent variables via s-functions and interactions via ti-functions; Wood, 2017). Our GAMs estimated multilevel growth models by predicting a dependent variable from the time variable.

div.head: Measures
div.p: Signal-Contingent Measures. We measured 10 variables at randomized times throughout the day using 6-point response scales, which ranged from 1 -Strongly Agree to 6 -Strongly Disagree in the following order.

The first question assessed the extent to which participants felt "good", "hungry", "uncertain", and "stressed", anchored by "At this moment, I feel…". Uncertainty and mood were measured for obfuscation and exploratory purposes.

Conflict about meat consumption was measured on an item adapted from scale-development research on felt ambivalence (Buttlar et al., 2023;Priester & Petty, 1996) using a 6-point response scale: "I feel some conflict in relation to meat consumption". We employed a single item to measure the principal facet of the construct of attitudinal conflict, consistent with previous experience sampling studies and research on ambivalence and dissonance (e.g., Pauer, Rutjens, Ruby, et al., 2022;Schneider et al., 2015;Vaidis et al., 2024).

Positive and negative evaluations were measured on a split-semantic-differential item each (Kaplan, 1972) thinking about the topic of meat consumption". We measured elaboration because previous research indicated that people experience felt ambivalence when inconsistent evaluations are simultaneously accessible (Newby-Clark et al., 2002;Pauer, Rutjens, Ruby, et al., 2022;van Harreveld et al., 2014).
Given that elaboration on an attitude object engenders the accessibility of evaluations of that object (Fazio, 1989), elaboration represents a pivotal precondition for attitudinal conflict.
We measured perceived freedom of choice on an item drawing on Armitage and Conner (1999) and : "I would be able to choose a meat-free dish for my next meal, if I wanted to".
Food choice and additional Variables. Participants reported the starting times of each lunch and dinner in separate event-contingent surveys, which averaged to 12:33 and 18:19, respectively.

Subsequently, they indicated their food choice on a 7-point response scale: "What proportion of the meal was meat?" (1 -only meat, 4 -about half, 7 -no meat). We included additional measures like situational context variables and dispositional scales for unrelated research questions, exploratory purposes, and obfuscation of research questions (all measures are listed in the preregistration and materials documents).

div.head: The Temporal Antecedents of Attitudinal Conflict
div.p: From early psychological theories to contemporary ones, it has been postulated that people experience attitudinal conflict when facing inconsistency (e.g., Hillman et al., 2022;Lewin, 1935).

The present section addresses the dynamic role of evaluative inconsistency (potential ambivalence) in experiencing attitudinal conflict (felt ambivalence) in daily life. This set of non-preregistered analyses investigated the temporal sequences of the association between evaluative inconsistency and attitudinal conflict as well as the evaluative components involved, drawing on our temporal framework of conflict emergence and resolution. The subsequent sections examine the roles of decision-making in attitudinal conflict and its association with inconsistency, as well as the dynamics of conflict regulation.

div.head: The Effect of Inconsistency on Attitudinal Conflict Over Time
div.p: Evaluations may fluctuate across daily-life contexts (Schwarz, 2007). A simple multilevel model showed that such momentary fluctuations in evaluative inconsistency correlated with attitudinal conflict in daily life, β = .23, b = 0.16, 95% CI[0.12, 0.19], p < .001. While this association between heightened inconsistency and conflict aligns with ample laboratory research that yielded similar effect sizes for a range of other attitude objects , the small magnitude corroborates the assumption that inconsistency elicits conflict especially in specific situations (which we will probe in a later section).

However, the association between evaluative inconsistency and attitudinal conflict may be bidirectional as people may form a more coherent attitude through effectively resolving attitudinal conflict (Dalege et al., 2019;van Harreveld et al., 2015). We therefore used a cross-lagged model (Myin-Germeys & Kuppens, 2021) to isolate the prospective effect of inconsistency on conflict over time. The model showed that increases in inconsistency preceded heightened conflict at the subsequent measurement (even after controlling for distance to the previous measurement, previous conflict, and momentary inconsistency), β = .08, b = 0.06, 95% CI[0.02, 0.09], p = .002 (see section S2 for details). The effect was significant for measurements taken up to 131 min. apart.

Our results show that attitudinal conflict indeed succeeded spikes in evaluative inconsistency in daily life, which adds to causal inference through a longitudinal analysis with high ecological validity (Grosz et al., 2020). Interestingly, the effect of inconsistency persisted for a finite yet relatively durable period of time. In line with our expectations, this suggests either that individuals have rapidly regulated the initial attitudinal conflict, but it was prone to resurface within the observed timeframe (Pauer, Rutjens, et al., 2023;Wegner et al., 1987), or the conflict faded gradually throughout the entire episode. Prevailing conflict theories have underspecified these dynamics in how people experience and resolve attitudinal conflict. This gap aligns with a widespread lack of research on the time windows and sequences of processes involved in psychological theories (Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023).

div.head: The Effects of Inconsistency and its Evaluative Bases on Attitudinal Conflict
div.p: The evaluative components that underlie inconsistency may have distinct effects on conflict (Cacioppo et al., 1997;Snyder & Tormala, 2017). Building on the gradual threshold model of ambivalence (GTM; Priester & Petty, 1996b), we first tested the notion that attitudinal conflict arises especially due to increases in evaluative components that oppose the dominant components (i.e., increases in negativity, given that people who follow a meat-based diet hold especially positive evaluations about meat; Hopwood et al., 2020Hopwood et al., , 2021. We did so by adding positive and negative evaluations to the aforementioned simple multilevel model of conflict predicted from inconsistency. To investigate the sequence by which evaluations and their inconsistency give rise to attitudinal conflict, we isolated the prospective roles of the evaluative components over time. We ran a cross-lagged model predicting attitudinal conflict from previous positive and negative evaluations and their inconsistency (controlling for their momentary values, the temporal distance of adjunct measurements, and prior conflict; Myin-Germeys & Kuppens, 2021). In this model, the roles of prior evaluative components turned non-significant (while the effect of prior inconsistency remained relevant, b = 0.05, 95% CI[0.00, 0.09], p = .046; see Table S2.2).
Taken together, evaluative components have distinct consequences in the dynamics of evaluative inconsistency in daily life, with a primary role of increases in the weaker components.

However, accounting for the temporal sequences of these processes, there were no directly predictive effects of the evaluative components on attitudinal conflict over time. This indicates that the inconsistency of the evaluations reflects a more proximal antecedent of experiencing conflict. These findings corroborate our framework of conflict emergence and resolution by demonstrating how fluctuations within different evaluative components lead to attitudinal conflict over time.

div.head: The Trajectory of Attitudinal Conflict During Decision-Making
div.p: Attitudinal conflict may constitute an episodic experience that arises especially when people have to make a choice (van Harreveld, Rutjens, et al., 2009). We therefore preregistered our prediction of a peak in conflict during naturally occurring episodes of decision-making (i.e., food choices), which is reported in the first part of the present section. The subsequent set of analyses further examined the expected interactive roles of evaluative inconsistency and decision-making during that episode of conflict.

div.head: How Does Attitudinal Conflict Evolve Over Time?
div.p: We employed a multilevel generalized additive model (GAM; Wood, 2017) to test our prediction of a peak in attitudinal conflict during food choice, which we investigated by modeling systematic trends in attitudinal conflict as a function of time (i.e., the temporal distance of a measurement of conflict to the nearest onset of food intake). The model revealed substantial systematic fluctuations in attitudinal conflict within individuals across time, F(5.39, 461) = 4.41, p < .001. The effective degrees of freedom of 5.39 reflect the degree of nonlinearity of the temporal fluctuations in conflict, with 1 corresponding to linear and 2 to approximately quadratic effects. As expected this shape of the fluctuations shows that the trajectory of attitudinal conflict over time is notably nonlinear, which we scrutinized next.

Attitudinal conflict peaked shortly before food intake, as evidenced by the 95% confidence intervals that excluded the baseline level of conflict (see Figure 3; Wood, 2017). Specifically, the conflict began to significantly surge 87 min. before the onset of the meal, reaching an inverse Ushaped tipping point at 36 min. preceding the event. We calculated the amplitude of this peak across all observations (see Section S3.1), amounting to 8.3% of the standard deviation. These findings support our prediction that attitudinal conflict peaks when people have to make a food choice.

The peak remained significant for 6 min. after the commencement of food intake. Such postdecisional experiences of conflict align with skin-conductance research by van Harreveld et al. (2009), indicating either a carry-over effect or behavior-induced conflict. However, the latter appears less likely given the steady decrease in conflict. Starting 48 min. after the onset of food intake, attitudinal conflict plateaued significantly below the baseline for 98 min. This valley could possibly reflect dampened conflict due to fatigue or dissonance reduction. Taken together, these findings highlight that attitudinal conflict traces a complex nonlinear trajectory during everyday decisionmaking. This underscores a dynamic nature of attitudinal conflict that involves a range of factors, which we will further investigate next. expected that this association would be particularly pronounced when the inconsistency becomes accessible during decision-making. To examine this prediction, we first report a base model of the interaction effect between evaluative inconsistency and time on attitudinal conflict. A second analysis probed the preregistered assumption that the rolling correlations between evaluative inconsistency and attitudinal conflict peak during food choices before a meal.

There was a significant interaction between inconsistency and time, F(7.13, 455) = 2.59, p = .005 (see Table S3.1). Momentary increases in inconsistency were associated with higher attitudinal conflict shortly before food intake (see Figure 4). Specifically, at heightened levels of inconsistency, the 95% Cis indicate that the peak in conflict is significantly above the baseline and more pronounced than at lowered inconsistency. This effect was, again, primarily driven by heightened negative rather than positive evaluations (see section S3.2 for details). The findings show an interaction between inconsistency and decision-making, while the previously reported main effect of inconsistency remained significant. This corroborates the notion that having to make a choice amplifies the effect of inconsistency on conflict.

Second, we scrutinized the contingency of the association between evaluative inconsistency and attitudinal conflict on decision-making. A GAM predicted the rolling correlations between both from time (i.e., distance to the nearest meal) and revealed significant temporal fluctuations, F(8.42, 371) = 18.40, p < .001, with the expected increase in the correlations before food intake (see Figure 3). Importantly, however, separate exploratory GAMs showed that inconsistency did not fluctuate systematically across time, F(1.01, 460) = 2.20, p = .137, neither did negative evaluations, F(1.00, 460) = 0.57, p = .451, nor positive evaluations, F(2.81, 459) = 2.02, p = .120. This pattern of results suggests that everyday decision-making engenders attitudinal conflict by heightening the mere salience of inconsistent evaluations, even without concordant momentary changes within the attitude.

Taken together, the data reveal that the propensity of evaluative inconsistency to elicit attitudinal conflict fluctuates systematically throughout the day. As predicted by our framework of conflict emergence and resolution, inconsistency is particularly consequential in situations where individuals need to act upon the attitude. This amplifying effect on the elicitation of attitudinal conflict is arguably due to the increased accessibility of inconsistent evaluations of the issue when people feel an urge to make a choice . Next, we will directly test this interaction between the necessity to make a choice and cognitive elaboration on the attitude object.

div.head: Figure 4
div.p: Changes in Attitudinal Conflict Predicted from Time, i.e., Distance to the Onset of a Meal, as a Figure S3.2

div.head: The Roles of Perceived Choice and Cognitive Accessibility
div.p: The model of ambivalence-induced discomfort (MAID; postulates that attitudinal conflict surges when people feel they have to make a choice and introspect on it, thereby increasing the accessibility of inconsistent evaluations. We operationalized this assumption by probing the interaction between time (i.e., distance to a meal), perceived choice, and cognitive elaboration, with the latter involving greater accessibility of inconsistency. This interaction effect on attitudinal conflict was significant, F(1.01, 473) = 7.96, p = .005 (see Table S3.3). As predicted, conflict significantly surfaced prior to food intake only when people reflected on the attitude object and felt in control over making a choice (see Figure 5). Notably, a second and inverse pattern emerged in the post-behavioral phase, with attitudinal conflict significantly attenuating below its baseline in conditions of heightened perceived choice and elaboration.

Given the pivotal role of cognitive accessibility of inconsistent evaluations in why decisionmaking elicits attitudinal conflict, we expected that hunger and stress inhibit the effect of decisionmaking on the peak in conflict. Contrary to this prediction, two separate interaction models yielded non-significant two-way interaction effects between time and hunger or stress on conflict, ps > .300 (see Tables S3.4 and S3.5). The surprising non-significant roles of stress and hunger could indicate that decision-making takes primacy over other situational factors in eliciting attitudinal conflict.

These findings provide direct support for the notion that perceived responsibility influences the emergence of attitudinal conflict and its regulation, aligning with our predictions. Overall, everyday decision-making determines the shapes of how attitudinal conflict arises, by drawing attention to evaluative inconsistency and necessitating individuals to commit to one side of the ambivalent attitude.

div.head: The Temporal Dynamics of Conflict Regulation
div.p: A particularly consequential motivation to reduce attitudinal conflict may arise when people engage in behavior that contradicts their attitudes, i.e., cognitive dissonance (Festinger, 1957; Harmon-Jones, 2019). We therefore investigated how attitudinal conflict evolves during the phase of naturally occurring dissonance. Given that our framework of conflict emergence and resolution proposes that attitudinal conflict motivates an interplay of multiple sequential processes, we examined the roles of two variables that may be consecutively involved in conflict regulation, i.e., denial of responsibility (i.e., emotion-focused coping) and evaluative spreading (i.e., problem-focused coping).

We hypothesized that people engage in these dissonance reduction strategies and downregulate attitudinal conflict when they enact the target behavior (i.e., eating meat) despite previously heightened negative evaluations of this choice (Bastian et al., 2012;Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Rothgerber, 2020). Preregistered statistical models of dissonance examined these dynamics by probing three-way interactions between time (i.e., distance to the onset of the nearest meal), engagement in the target behavior, and negative evaluation of it at the measurement point prior to the behavior.

div.head: Denial of Responsibility
div.p: We expected that dissonance motivates denial of responsibility. Contrary to this prediction, the predictive effect of the three-way interaction model of dissonance on perceived freedom of choice was non-significant, F(4.16, 440) = 0.52, p = .811 (see Table S4.1). Instead, there was a significant two-way interaction between time and food choice, F(3.69, 440) = 21.47, p < .001, such that perceived choice dropped substantially below the baseline at the onset of eating meat regardless of prior negative evaluations (see Figure 6). This pattern of findings seems partly in line with self-perception theory (Bem, 1967), which posits changes in beliefs due to past behavior, even without the motivational effect of dissonance (Albarracín & Wyer, 2000). In fact, people tended to report higher degrees of perceived choice during a meal even in the absence of dissonance. However, given that the effect was more pronounced during the target behavior (meat consumption) and was only short-lived, another explanation is that people habitually downregulated perceived choice during the target behavior to protect against the elicitation of dissonant discomfort, corroborating the motivated account of moral reasoning (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017).

div.head: Evaluative Spreading
div.p: We modeled evaluative spreading of positive and negative evaluations by estimating their rolling correlations across time. The three-way interaction model of dissonance predicted evaluative spreading, F(2.54, 315) = 2.63, p = .046 (see Table S4.2). After dissonance, the correlation was r = -.48 at the onset of behavior and, eventually, it leveled off closely to this coefficient in all conditions except for a steady decrease to r = -.61 in the dissonance condition (see Figure 6). The correlation thus became increasingly negative over time, supporting our preregistered hypothesis. This shift towards attitudinal alignment reveals a relatively durable effect of dissonance on evaluative spreading.

The dissonance condition exhibited a delayed onset of evaluative spreading, occurring more than one hour after the behavior began. While evaluative spreading may set in at a late stage of dissonance reduction (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020), one could have expected an earlier onset during the hot phase of behavioral enactment. A potential explanation for the surprising latency is that temporal distance to the behavior might have facilitated spreading through increasing the accessibility of generalized evaluations of the behavior category, rather than its specific instance. This might involve, for example, referring to the typical pleasure associated with eating meat or beliefs about its naturalness (Hopwood et al., 2021;Piazza et al., 2015). Such categorical justifications may become more prevalent after rather than during an instance of the behavior if generating a justification for that specific instance is difficult.

Interestingly, evaluative components spread within a temporary episode after food intake even when prior negative evaluations were low. This could reflect evaluative spreading that has become habitual due to previous experiences with dissonance reduction (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Buttlar, Pauer, & van Harreveld, 2024). Congruently, the correlations between positive and negative evaluations in this condition eventually stabilized at a value statistically indistinguishable from the initial coefficient, suggesting that relatively effortless processes led to the inconsequential attitudinal fluctuation (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986). Overall, instances of cognitive dissonance influenced the downstream dynamics of evaluative spreading over time, rather than its initial onset. This evaluative spreading succeeded the aforementioned effect on responsibility diffusion, aligning with our assertion that people engage in sequential reactions to attitudinal conflict.

div.head: Post-behavioral Conflict
div.p: Given that our primary aim was to investigate the dynamics of attitudinal conflict over time, we finally tested our prediction that dissonance motivates people to downregulate attitudinal conflict.

There was a significant three-way interaction effect of dissonance on conflict, F(5.57, 461) = 2.35, p = .021 (see Table S4.3). Attitudinal conflict significantly fluctuated over time only after dissonance (see Figure 6). At the onset of meal intake, conflict levels were significantly higher than the average in the dissonance condition, which is consistent with laboratory research on dissonance (e.g., Sleegers et al., 2023). However, dissonance did not evoke heightened conflict, as indicated by the confidence bands that initially overlapped with the slope of conflict following attitude-consistent behavior.
Instead, attitudinal conflict declined shortly after the onset of the dissonant behavior, as expected.
This underscores the value of intensive longitudinal data by revealing a temporary phase of conflict downregulation during the onset of attitude-inconsistent behavior.

This pattern of initial conflict regulation opposed the temporal patterns of responsibility diffusion and evaluative spreading, suggesting that alternative coping strategies may have played a more central role in downregulating conflict in this phase of conflict regulation. These strategies could include dissonance-induced thought suppression or forgetting (Elkin & Leippe, 1986), aligning with our assertion that people regulate attitudinal conflict by engaging in effortless coping strategies as long as these are effective. This contrasts with the aforementioned pattern of findings observed during the pre-decisional phase, where evaluative inconsistency increased attitudinal conflict, reflecting attention to the inconsistency in order to reach a decision. Once people have begun to enact a behavior that is inconsistent with their attitude, however, it may be easier to downregulate attitudinal conflict and maintain the course of action, rather than reversing the conflicted decision that led to the behavior (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Harmon-Jones et al., 2009).

A succeeding phase yielded relatively stable levels of attitudinal conflict, mirrored by plateaus in evaluative spreading and responsibility diffusion. This may reflect that people have successfully downregulated conflict beforehand to enable unconflicted action-taking, in line the action-based model of dissonance (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Harmon-Jones et al., 2009).By extension, there should be less need to prevent attitudinal conflict after the behavior is enacted, since conflict no longer interferes with the course of action. Accordingly, conflict slightly increased about one hour after the behavior began.

Subsequently, attitudinal conflict further declined within the dissonance condition. One possible explanation is a reduced accessibility of inconsistency due to fatigue from digestive functions. However, the decline in conflict coincided with the onset of evaluative spreading.

Therefore, evaluative shifts could have contributed to the downregulation of conflict. Attitudinal conflict eventually reverted and became statistically indistinguishable from the levels of conflict in the baseline condition. The late surge in attitudinal conflict may be a consequence of a growing temporal distance to the attitude-inconsistent behavior, leading to a reappearance of attitudinal conflict, in line with our framework of conflict emergence and resolution. These findings corroborate our assertion that people engage in sequential attempts to regulate attitudinal conflict and highlight the dynamic processes involved in how people experience and respond to the conflict in naturalistic settings.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: In modern society, the ubiquitous presence of choice overload often gives rise to attitudinal conflict in everyday life (Chernev et al., 2015). The current investigation employs a temporal perspective on such experiences to shed light on the processes and situational factors that evoke attitudinal conflict and its motivational consequences. Our framework of conflict emergence and resolution delineates the entire trajectory of how attitudinal conflict unfolds, which we tested in utilizing a powerful synergy between experience sampling methods (ESM) and a novel integrated sampling approach. In this vein, the present work integrates previous research that predominantly examined attitudinal conflict at a single phase of the decision-making process, by illuminating the dynamic processes and consequences of attitudinal conflict as they unfold naturally in daily life.

The findings corroborate our framework by revealing that attitudinal conflict is an episodic phenomenon with low transience, tracing a prolonged nonlinear trajectory. This episodic yet complex experience underscores the importance of the sequence in which the inconsistency of evaluations, along with situational factors, gives rise to attitudinal conflict over time. While evaluative components differed in their propensity to produce evaluative inconsistency (potential ambivalence), the latter gave rise to experiences of attitudinal conflict (felt ambivalence; Dalege et al., 2019;Priester & Petty, 1996). As this effect was relatively durable over prolonged periods, resolving the attitudinal origin of the conflict may be challenging and thereby result in low transience and reappearances of it.

Furthermore, the data reveal that the role of decision-making in evoking attitudinal conflict represents a key determinant of why inconsistency leads to attitudinal conflict. This effect was driven by the heightened cognitive accessibility of the inconsistency when people feel an urge to decide.

Our findings indicate that attitudinal conflict dissolves relatively inertially, whereas engaging in counter-attitudinal behavior motivates a steeper decline (i.e., dissonance reduction; Festinger, 1957). After downregulating the conflict, it plateaued during the course of behavioral engagement, presumably to enable people to effectively implement the conflicted behavioral choice (Harmon-Jones et al., 2009). Despite initially effective downregulation, attitudinal conflict reappeared in a later phase of conflict regulation. This resurgence of the conflict may be one reason why people engage in sequential regulatory attempts in response to attitudinal conflict. Specifically, individuals employ effortless coping strategies as long as these strategies reduce the conflict (Cancino-Montecinos et al., 2020;, such that the reappearance of the conflict motivates more problem-focused resolution attempts to reconcile the attitudinal origins of the conflict. The data tentatively indicate that an initial response to attitudinal conflict can even involve habitual regulation attempts (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017), such as temporary responsibility diffusion in parallel to other regulatory strategies. Taken together, these findings demonstrate the value of a temporal perspective in explaining the antecedents and consequences of naturally occurring conflict in the real world. Our framework of conflict emergence and resolution integrates and extends prior research by highlighting the pivotal roles of sequential phases and their transitions in the dynamic processes underlying attitudinal conflict and its consequences.

The present work makes significant contributions to the existing literature on attitudinal conflict for a number of additional reasons. First, it bridges the literature on cognitive dissonance with that on attitudinal ambivalence. Although Festinger's (1957) original conceptualization of cognitive dissonance also encapsulates the intra-attitudinal conflict that constitutes ambivalence, empirical research on dissonance has almost exclusively focused on discrepancies between attitudes and behavior (Harmon-Jones, 2019;McGregor et al., 2019). While these two kinds of conflict therefore exist within largely separate literatures, we have tied them together on a temporal dimension, spanning from pre-decisional conflict (ambivalence) to post-decisional conflict (dissonance).

Conceptually relating the two types of conflict to one another may inform future research in both areas. A second contribution of the present work lies in providing empirical support for the conflictmitigating effects of coping strategies. The literature on dissonance and ambivalence postulates that strategies such as the spreading of alternatives can reduce conflict (e.g., Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Dalege et al., 2019;. However, this assertion is seldom tested empirically (Gradidge et al., 2021;van Harreveld et al., 2015). Our work offers insight into the extent to which coping strategies are employed and their effectiveness.

From a methodological perspective, our study spans the entire decision-making process and its dynamics by integrating data from both event-and signal-contingent sampling procedures. This integrated sampling approach enables precise measurements of naturally occurring decisional outcomes and their timing, along with a fine-grained and uninterrupted resolution of within-subject processes throughout the entire decisional circle. The innovative methodology presents a rigorous means to investigate the temporal patterns of psychological phenomena surrounding events that occur at unpredictable timepoints in real-world settings (see Figure 2). Future studies can adopt our integrated sampling approach to meet the growing demand for research into the temporal dynamics of the processes underlying attitudinal conflict (A. McGrath, 2017;Vaidis & Bran, 2019) and human experiences more generally (Diener et al., 2022;Gainsburg et al., 2023;Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023;Hohm et al., 2024;Yarkoni, 2022), such as to track how naturally occurring moral actions influence moral cognition over time (for more examples, see Hofmann & Grigoryan, 2023, pp. 31-32). In situations where real-time self-reporting of events is unfeasible, automatic mobile sensing emerges as a valuable supplement to self-reported data, such as by tracking bodily movements and proximity of a smartphone to other devices (Harari & Gosling, 2023;Roos et al., 2023). Researchers can integrate such recordings of event timings with self-reports to unravel complex phenomena, like the sequence of processes by which intergroup contact influences inter-and intrapersonal conflict or prejudice, for example.

The high ecological validity and fine-grained temporal resolution of the study offer applicable insights for behavior change campaigns. As we conducted the study in the context of food choices about meat consumption, the observed dynamics of attitudinal conflict inform the optimal timing of interventions aimed at supporting people in adopting more healthy and sustainable plant-based diets.

Specifically, ample research has shown that attitudinal conflict motivates people to process information that can facilitate conflict regulation (e.g., Clark et al., 2008;, such that peaks in meat-related conflict reflect opportunity windows for supporting individuals. Targeting interventional information to specific times of attitudinal conflict and omitting the times at which people are likely to engage in dissonance reduction may increase the cost-effectiveness of behavior change campaigns. Policy-makers, non-profit organizations, and social marketing agencies could further amplify this effect by designing intervention contents that facilitate the regulation of meatrelated conflict through a willingness to change (Bastian, 2019;Brouwer et al., 2022;Minson & Chen, 2022;Pauer, Gainsburg, et al., 2023). We expect that numerous domains that entail frequent attitudinal conflicts involve similar opportunities for targeting interventions to their temporal dynamics, such as for recycling, physical exercise, and smoking cessation (Hahn et al., 2021;.

Another promising avenue for future research is to examine potential boundary conditions of the pattern of findings observed in our data. Given the prevalent moral concerns surrounding the topic of meat consumption, which often elicit attitudinal conflict in this domain (Buttlar et al., 2023;Pauer, Rutjens, Ruby, et al., 2022), its attitudinal bases may be more stable compared to those in less moralized attitude objects (Luttrell & Togans, 2021). Once people cannot prevent the experience of conflict within a moralized attitude object, however, it might involve a more effortful sequence of attempts to resolve the origin of the conflict (Feinberg et al., 2019;Finkhäuser et al., 2024;Pauer, Rutjens, et al., 2023). In addition, previous research suggests that people have evolved to prevent dissonant experiences related to moralized behaviors like eating meat in daily life through societal adaptations and individual habits (Bastian & Loughnan, 2017;Piazza et al., 2023). Future research could thus benefit from studying how the sequence of processes by which attitudinal conflict arises and dissolves differ by moralization and habitualization of a domain.

div.head: Statement of Limitations
div.p: Our work also has limitations, like all psychological research (see Table 1). Our primary aim was to investigate how episodic experiences of attitudinal conflict and its consequences unfold over time. The time window of our analysis was therefore optimized for observing dynamics throughout the decisional phases. Although this method exhibits a high temporal resolution, it does not record attitudinal conflicts that can operate without an individual's awareness (e.g., Faure et al., 2022;Petty et al., 2006;Schneider & Schwarz, 2017), leading to an underestimated prevalence of conflict.

Likewise, the study disregarded more long-lived dynamics in attitudinal conflict. For instance, frequent experiences of attitudinal conflict motivate people to engage in more effective coping strategies , such that conflict regulation could arguably lead to diminished attitudinal conflict at subsequent episodes of decision-making (Buttlar, Pauer, & van Harreveld, 2024). Future research needs to investigate such cross-situation dynamics and the sequence of processes by which people ultimately reconcile ambivalent attitudes.

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Summary of Limitations

• The experience sampling study (ESM) comprises correlational data from naturalistic settings, allowing for causal inferences through modeling processes over time, for example. But it precludes some other kinds of causal inferences.
We hope that our framework will particularly encourage experimental research to investigate the processes surrounding attitudinal conflict from a temporal perspective.
• Our research focusses on a medium-term time window of processes rather than subliminal and more long-term dynamics.
• There may be boundary conditions, including the degree to which an attitude object involves moralization and habitualization.

• Self-report items are prone to socially desirable responding and other biases (e.g., Miller et al., 2008;Rothgerber, 2018). For example, people who score high in preference for consistency might feel conflicted when merely responding to items on both positive and negative evaluations of an attitude object (Newby-Clark et al., 2002).While it has been argued that experience sampling substantially minimizes such biases (Myin-Germeys & Kuppens, 2021;Trull & Ebner-Priemer, 2013), the within-subjects design employed in our work further attenuates this limitation by focusing on fluctuations within individuals across repeated measurements of real-time processes.

• We used single-item scales to assess the principal facets of our target constructs, as is typical in experience sampling studies. While the measurement quality of single items is similar to multi-item scales of typical psychological concepts, the possible limitations are partly offset by a combination of interaction models, high statistical power, and within-subjects analyses of in-time assessments (Ahmad et al., 2014;Allen et al., 2022;Bolger & Laurenceau, 2013).

• While the study sample comprised a diverse age range and low student and unemployment rates compared to other ESM studies, participants were exclusively from the U.K.. Although attitudinal conflict is arguably a universal experience (Festinger, 1957;, there might be variation in the extent to which people experience such conflict and how they regulate it (Gawronski, 2012;Heine & Lehman, 1997). For example, individuals with a higher tolerance for inconsistency might more readily engage in acceptance following a conflicted choice, potentially shortening the period of dissonance reduction.

Attitudinal conflicts shape various characteristics of human life, ranging from the outcomes of financial decision-making to interpersonal interactions and moral progress. The present work proposes that a comprehension of the nature of experiences of conflict requires insight into the temporal dimensions of the processes involved. By elucidating how attitudinal conflict naturally progresses over time and embedded within episodic and sequential processes, our research contributes to advancing towards a more ecologically and temporally accurate understanding of human behavior and its psychological dynamics as they unfold in everyday life. This research was funded by grants from Studienstiftung (German Academic Scholarship Foundation) to SP and from the Animal Advocacy Research Fund to SP, BR, and FvH. The funding providers did not play any role in any part of the research process.

Momentary increases in negative evaluations were most predictive of conflict, b = 0.29, 95% CI[0.23, 0.36], p < .001. The effect of inconsistency substantially decreased but remained significant, b = 0.05, 95% CI[0.01, 0.09], p = .019, and positive evaluations had an inhibitory effect, b = -0.15, 95% CI[-0.20, -0.10], p < .001. In line with the GTM, this pattern of results indicates that attitudinal conflict arises from momentary increases in the weaker evaluative component.
